questions.Description: At Ameren, all data is classified in 4 broad categories depending on its sensitivity. To learn more click here:
questions.Name: What is the classification of data involved in your project?

questions.Description: Typically you will need some kind of storage (think database) to store your data. This storage can be hosted inside the Ameren Data Center (on-prem network), or externally.

questions.Description: Click here for more details:
questions.Name: Does the solution involve integration with or management of Ameren control systems?

questions.Description: Click here for more details:
questions.Name: Who will access the Ameren data?

questions.Description: Data can be accessed via devices that are managed by Ameren admin (eg. Airwatch managed mobile devices) or it can be accessed via devices that are not under Ameren admin's control (eg. contractor using their cell phone to access files in Office 365).
questions.Name: In your project or solution how will Ameren data be accessed?

questions.Description: Encryption of data is important. If bad actors get hold of Ameren data storage (database disks), they will be unable to make sense of it if its encrypted using a strong encryption algorithm like SHA 256. Click here to learn more:
questions.Name: Is Ameren data encrypted at rest?

questions.Description: It is important that when you are transferring data across the internet or across networks, you encrypt data. This will prevent from 'Man in the middle attacks' - a term used to describe programs or bad actors trying to hack into the system by listening to the traffic on the wire. Ckick here to learn more:
questions.Name: Is Ameren data encrypted in transit?

questions.Description: See the help section for the Preferred Tech List
questions.Name: Does software adhere to Ameren's preferred technology list?

questions.Name: Is the Netskope rating of the product/solution you plan on using above 50?

questions.Description: Many apps will require to integrate with existing Ameren systems in order to provide meaningful services. Sometimes an app or a solution maybe completely standalone with no integration requirements. When integration is required however, it is important to understand if the new app/solution will be accessing any systems that reside inside Ameren data center (examples include ADMS, CSS etc.)
questions.Name: Assuming your solution requires access to Ameren's network including Ameren's control systems what is the integration pattern you will use?

questions.Description: It is generally a good practice to allow role based access to your systems. See help for more details:
questions.Name: Does the application support role-based authorization?

questions.Description: At Ameren we use Microsoft Active Directory to manage employee and contractor usernames and passwords. Sometimes a solution requires you to implement its own identiy system to manage its users. Click here to learn more:
questions.Name: Assuming your solution uses a secondary user identity store, can this identity store be disabled?

Options.Name: Not applicable (solution implements SSO With AD)

questions.answer: Not applicable (solution implements SSO With AD)

questions.Name: Does the product's administration role support multi-factor authentication?

questions.Description: This will help determine the risk, should the product not support SSO
questions.Name: Roughly how many users will be using your solution/product/application?

questions.Name: If this solution deals with PCI, HIPPA, NERC, FERC, NRC or SOX data does it adhere to their standards.

questions.Description: It is a very good practice to backup data to prevent from accidental loss , theft and also for disaster recovery purposes.
questions.Name: Is any customer data backed up to a different location other than Ameren Data Center or Ameren AWS VPC?

questions.Description: From a regulatory standpoint it is very important that Ameren stores all data inside the US. Click here to learn more:
questions.Name: Is the data and its backup always stored inside the US?

-LLojKSjK5Arh3GKZfah.description:
JFrog Xray performs artifact analysis for all major package formats 
across the CI/CD pipeline.

JFrog Xray starts with your primary software component, and then recursively drills down to identify its dependencies, and then the dependencies dependencies, and so on down to any level, until every single component that is a part of your software, whether directly or indirectly, has been identified. Xray supports a variety of major packaging formats in use today including Docker, Debian, RPM, NuGet, JAR files, Npm, PyPI and Bower. In fact, as an open and flexible package-agnostic tool, Xray can accommodate new formats that may come on the scene from time to time and provide the same level of deep recursive scanning as with currently available package formats.

Lost 5 points since non-sensitive data is outside USA
